metadata.description: Comprehensive database of relative risk estimates for mortality calculations
metadata.data_integrity_note: All values sourced from peer-reviewed literature and meta-analyses
metadata.population_specificity: U.S.-specific estimates preferred for U.S. baseline mortality calculations. Global estimates clearly marked and should be used with caution.
metadata.methodological_note: Relative risks from global studies may not reflect U.S. population-specific risk due to differences in healthcare access, smoking patterns, and population demographics.

smoking.description: Relative risks for smoking status on all-cause mortality
smoking.source: Jha et al. (2013) - U.S. specific, GBD 2019 - Global reference
smoking.notes: U.S.-specific estimates preferred for U.S. baseline mortality calculations. Global estimates may over/underestimate risk due to population differences.

current_vs_never.source: Jha P, Ramasundarahettige C, Landsman V, et al. 21st-century hazards of smoking and benefits of cessation in the United States. NEJM 2013
current_vs_never.notes: U.S.-specific estimate for current smokers vs never smokers. Age-adjusted relative risk for all-cause mortality in U.S. population.

current_vs_never_global.source: GBD 2019: Global Burden of Disease Study 2019 results
current_vs_never_global.notes: Global estimate - may not reflect U.S. population-specific risk. Use with caution for U.S. calculations.

former_vs_never.source: Doll R, Peto R. Mortality in relation to smoking: 50 years' observations on British doctors. BMJ 2005
former_vs_never.notes: Risk for former smokers vs never smokers

years_to_never_equivalent.source: Jha P, Ramasundarahettige C, Landsman V, et al. 21st-century hazards of smoking and benefits of cessation in the United States. NEJM 2013
years_to_never_equivalent.notes: Years after quitting to reach never-smoker risk levels

blood_pressure.description: Relative risks for systolic blood pressure on cardiovascular mortality
blood_pressure.source: Lewington S, Clarke R, Qizilbash N, et al. Age-specific relevance of usual blood pressure to vascular mortality. Lancet 2002
blood_pressure.notes: Each 20 mmHg increase in SBP doubles cardiovascular mortality risk. Treatment reduces risk by ~30%.

per_20mmhg_sbp.source: Lewington S, Clarke R, Qizilbash N, et al. Age-specific relevance of usual blood pressure to vascular mortality: a meta-analysis of individual data for one million adults in 61 prospective studies. Lancet 2002
per_20mmhg_sbp.notes: Relative risk per 20 mmHg increase in systolic blood pressure

treatment_reduction.source: Blood Pressure Lowering Treatment Trialists' Collaboration. Blood pressure lowering for prevention of cardiovascular disease and death: a systematic review and meta-analysis. Lancet 2016
treatment_reduction.notes: 30% reduction in cardiovascular events with antihypertensive treatment

bmi.description: Relative risks for body mass index on all-cause mortality
bmi.source: Global BMI Mortality Collaboration. Body-mass index and all-cause mortality: individual-participant-data meta-analysis of 239 prospective studies. Lancet 2016
bmi.notes: J-shaped relationship with optimal BMI around 22-25. Risk increases with both underweight and overweight.

per_5_units.source: Global BMI Mortality Collaboration. Body-mass index and all-cause mortality: individual-participant-data meta-analysis of 239 prospective studies in four continents. Lancet 2016
per_5_units.notes: Relative risk per 5-unit increase in BMI above optimal range

optimal_range.source: Same as above - Global BMI Mortality Collaboration
optimal_range.notes: Optimal BMI range for lowest mortality risk

fitness.description: Relative risks for cardiorespiratory fitness on all-cause mortality
fitness.source: Kodama S, Saito K, Tanaka S, et al. Cardiorespiratory fitness as a quantitative predictor of all-cause mortality and cardiovascular events in healthy men and women. JAMA 2009
fitness.notes: Each MET improvement reduces mortality risk by ~10-15%. Sedentary lifestyle increases risk significantly.

per_met.source: Kodama S, Saito K, Tanaka S, et al. Cardiorespiratory fitness as a quantitative predictor of all-cause mortality and cardiovascular events in healthy men and women: a meta-analysis. JAMA 2009
per_met.notes: 15% reduction in mortality risk per MET improvement

sedentary_vs_active.source: Warburton DE, Nicol CW, Bredin SS. Health benefits of physical activity: the evidence. CMAJ 2006
sedentary_vs_active.notes: 40% higher mortality risk for sedentary vs active individuals

alcohol.description: Relative risks for alcohol consumption on all-cause mortality
alcohol.source: Di Castelnuovo A, Costanzo S, Bagnardi V, et al. Alcohol dosing and total mortality in men and women. Arch Intern Med 2006
alcohol.notes: J-shaped relationship with moderate consumption showing protective effect, heavy consumption increasing risk.

moderate_vs_none.source: Di Castelnuovo A, Costanzo S, Bagnardi V, et al. Alcohol dosing and total mortality in men and women: an updated meta-analysis of 34 prospective studies. Arch Intern Med 2006
moderate_vs_none.notes: 10% lower mortality risk with moderate alcohol consumption

heavy_vs_none.source: Same as above - Di Castelnuovo et al.
heavy_vs_none.notes: 30% higher mortality risk with heavy alcohol consumption

binge_vs_none.source: Roerecke M, Rehm J. Irregular heavy drinking occasions and risk of ischemic heart disease: a systematic review and meta-analysis. Am J Epidemiol 2010
binge_vs_none.notes: 20% higher mortality risk with binge drinking patterns

interventions.description: Effect sizes for lifestyle interventions on mortality risk
interventions.notes: Effect sizes for major lifestyle interventions based on clinical trials and cohort studies.

quit_smoking.source: Doll R, Peto R. Mortality in relation to smoking: 50 years' observations on British doctors. BMJ 2005
quit_smoking.notes: 20% immediate reduction in mortality risk upon quitting smoking

reduce_bp_10mmhg.source: Blood Pressure Lowering Treatment Trialists' Collaboration. Lancet 2016
reduce_bp_10mmhg.notes: 15% reduction in mortality risk per 10 mmHg SBP reduction

improve_fitness.source: Kodama S, Saito K, Tanaka S, et al. JAMA 2009
improve_fitness.notes: 10% reduction in mortality risk per MET improvement

lose_weight_5bmi.notes: 10% reduction in mortality risk per 5 BMI units lost
